articles.headline: Chicago Pays Millions but Punishes Few in Killings by Police
articles.snippet: The city spent more than $500 million settling police cases since 2004, but a vast majority of complaints against the police still do not result in discipline.
articles.abstract: The city spent more than $500 million settling police cases since 2004, but a vast majority of complaints against the police still do not result in discipline.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The gunshots blasted on and on, 45 in all, until Calvin Cross lay dead in a vacant lot. Mr. Cross, 19, had run away after three Chicago police officers pulled alongside him on a South Side street near his house. Bullets hit his chest, arm, back, face and the little finger on his right hand.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Timothy Williams

articles.headline: VW Names Kenneth Feinberg to Oversee Fund for Claims on Emissions Deception
articles.snippet: Mr. Feinberg is a compensation fund specialist who worked with victims of 9/11, the BP oil spill, the Boston Marathon bombing and General Motors’ ignition defect.
articles.abstract: Mr. Feinberg is a compensation fund specialist who worked with victims of 9/11, the BP oil spill, the Boston Marathon bombing and General Motors’ ignition defect.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen has hired Kenneth R. Feinberg, a prominent specialist in compensation funds, to devise and administer a program to address claims related to vehicles that have been affected by the company’s admitted use of deceptive software to cheat on emissions tests.

articles.headline: The Junk Bond Rout That Wasn’t
articles.snippet: Some worried that the doomed Third Avenue fund could foreshadow a crisis, but others say it was an outlier that doesn’t signal systemic problems.
articles.abstract: Some worried that the doomed Third Avenue fund could foreshadow a crisis, but others say it was an outlier that doesn’t signal systemic problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: After seven years of rock-bottom interest rates, it should come as no surprise to see excessive risk taking on Wall Street. Investors have long been trying to identify the next bubble, and last Friday Carl Icahn, the billionaire activist investor, weighed in.

articles.headline: Shkreli Indictment Portrays Small-Time Fraud
articles.snippet: The latest uproar around Martin Shkreli has nothing to do with drug prices, but allegations of fraud at a small hedge fund.
articles.abstract: The latest uproar around Martin Shkreli has nothing to do with drug prices, but allegations of fraud at a small hedge fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli told investors that his hedge fund had an auditor, that it had posted a 36 percent return since its inception and that it had $35 million in assets under management.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Martin Shkreli’s Arrest Gives Drug Makers Cover
articles.snippet: Pharmaceutical executives can look at the federal indictment and say that Martin Shkreli is an aberration, a rotten apple, but his arrest is not likely to make concern about drug prices go away.
articles.abstract: Pharmaceutical executives can look at the federal indictment and say that Martin Shkreli is an aberration, a rotten apple, but his arrest is not likely to make concern about drug prices go away.
articles.lead_paragraph: During his three months as a household name, Martin Shkreli has been a walking, talking (incessantly) personification of one of the pharmaceutical industry’s worst nightmares — the greedy drug company executive.

articles.headline: Democrats and Bernie Sanders Clash Over Data Breach
articles.snippet: The dispute came after members of Senator Bernie Sanders’s data team were found to have gotten access to proprietary information from Hillary Clinton’s team during a software glitch with an important voter file.
articles.abstract: The dispute came after members of Senator Bernie Sanders’s data team were found to have gotten access to proprietary information from Hillary Clinton’s team during a software glitch with an important voter file.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: After Years of War in Syria, U.N. Passes Resolution on Talks
articles.snippet: For the first time in the nearly five-year civil war in Syria, the Security Council backed a process for resolving the conflict.
articles.abstract: For the first time in the nearly five-year civil war in Syria, the Security Council backed a process for resolving the conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — For the first time since the nearly five-year-old Syrian civil war began, world powers agreed on Friday at the United Nations Security Council to embrace a plan for a cease-fire and a peace process that holds the distant prospect of ending the conflict.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Scarred Riverbeds and Dead Pistachio Trees in a Parched Iran
articles.snippet: Iran is in the grip of a seven-year drought that many experts believe is the new normal, and even a return to past rainfall levels might not be enough to prevent a national crisis.
articles.abstract: Iran is in the grip of a seven-year drought that many experts believe is the new normal, and even a return to past rainfall levels might not be enough to prevent a national crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: POUZE KHOON, Iran — The early-morning sun meagerly brightened the gloom of this sad township, a collection of empty, crumbling houses along a highway through the dusty desert landscape in southeastern Iran.

articles.headline: Congress Passes $1.8 Trillion Spending Measure
articles.snippet: After a period of belt-tightening in Washington, the measure provides a notable spending increase and tax breaks worth more than $620 billion.
articles.abstract: After a period of belt-tightening in Washington, the measure provides a notable spending increase and tax breaks worth more than $620 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After years of dysfunction and abysmal public approval ratings, a chastened, even beaten-down Congress on Friday passed a $1.8 trillion package of spending and tax cuts with remarkably little rancor.

articles.headline: ‘Star Wars’ Opens Amid Hype and Nostalgia
articles.snippet: Americans lined up on Thursday night for the beginning of round-the-clock screenings.
articles.abstract: Americans lined up on Thursday night for the beginning of round-the-clock screenings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Was “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” the most anticipated movie of all time? It can’t quite compare with the hoopla when “Gone With the Wind” arrived in 1939 and an estimated 300,000 fans flooded Atlanta, many in antebellum outfits. Georgia’s governor declared a state holiday.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Another Delay for an Upstart Stock Exchange
articles.snippet: The Investors’ Exchange hopes to clear the field of high-frequency trading and make investing fair for most investors. So why is the S.E.C. delaying again?
articles.abstract: The Investors’ Exchange hopes to clear the field of high-frequency trading and make investing fair for most investors. So why is the S.E.C. delaying again?
articles.lead_paragraph: Scores of investors, in a fistful of comments, have told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they want to be able to trade stocks on a more level playing field. So why hasn’t the commission, known as the Investor Advocate, given the green light to an operation that would enable it?

articles.headline: China’s Renminbi Declines After Being Named a Global Currency, Posing Challenges
articles.snippet: If China’s currency falls too steeply, the volatility could prompt traders to place large bets on further depreciation, making the decline harder to control.
articles.abstract: If China’s currency falls too steeply, the volatility could prompt traders to place large bets on further depreciation, making the decline harder to control.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At the end of last month, the Chinese renminbi was anointed as one of the world’s elite currencies, a first for an emerging market and a widely hailed acknowledgment of China’s rising financial influence and economic might.
